reviewText: Though hampered by the occasional bout of unpredictably frustrating physics, Tiny Brains is unique and creative enough that you forget to care. It's clear that the game was designed with multiplayer at the forefront, as playing solo is possible but significantly less rewarding. Multiplayer can be in the form of couch or online co-op or competitive play, and features gameplay so fun that it's difficult to get too worked up over the potential failures of your teammates.\n\nThe game never wants you to take it seriously, and that framework is part of what makes the game work so well. It's charming, packs a killer ear-wormy soundtrack, and offers brain teasing gameplay that will no doubt remind you of Portal. Though the main story campaign is pretty short, the package you get from the multiplayer is more than worth the price tag.

reviewText:
Buyer Beware! Check the game for updates. I bought the game during steam sale for $2, and I didn't check.

If the most recent update is still Mar 27, 2014, then multiplayer over internet is broken (players can not join a game over the internet, they get dropped from the game and sent back to the lobby) leaving you unable to play with friends (you will be sad).
On the forums, the Developer promised an update in the beginning of April, but it has never shipped, and the game is still broken.

Tl;Dr: If the game was last updated Mar 27, 2014, Multiplayer is broken, don't buy it until it is fixed by the developer. (14 weeks and counting)

reviewText:
Faulty's scorecard :-

1) Essential purchase
2) Recommended purchase
3) Recommended purchase during a sale4) Not recommended unless heavily discounted
5) Not even recommended for Steam game collectors

In the name of Science
Tiny Brains, the puzzle adventure from Spearhead Games, fits squarely into the category Portal/Portal 2, Quantum Conundrum and Q.U.B.E occupy and whilst it's definitely the weakest link when compared to any of the above it's still certainly worth a play-through if you enjoy these kinds of humorous cerebral experiences. While the game is playable in single-player you are definitely going to want to round up three other friends because this is where Tiny Brains comes alive much like Portal 2 did once you stepped into the shoes of either ATLAS or P-BODY.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=292297519
Much of Tiny Brains humor comes from experimenting with different possible solutions to the tasks you face and with three friends involved this can often be a laugh-out-loud riot. I will admit there were times my sides were nearly splitting from laughing so much at what had just befallen one of my online team mates or even one of my own silly foibles that lead to my untimely death that had the rest of the group roaring with laughter.

Tiny Brains sees you take on one of four different mice who have each been genetically altered by a mad scientist. Each mouse comes with a single physics-based power that must be used in conjunction with the other mice's power and/or environment in order to navigate their way through the challening and often barking-mad labyrinth the scientist has set up for them in an attempt to escape the laboratory they find themselves imprisoned in.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=294975812
As the players advance, the puzzles that require solving become a little tougher and more interesting ways for your little charge to meet his untimely end are introduced. My personal favorite was either flinging or being flung under a piston like object that if not done done correctly would see the one being flung squashed to bits. The puzzles do get interesting the further along you progress but none of them stood out in the same way the puzzles from Portal 2 or Quantum Conundrum did although there were many times the team was left scratching theirs heads, furiously trying to think of the solution in an attempt to outwit one another.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=292297044
Where Tiny Brains falters is with its glitches and bugs galore - of which there are too many to mention and this somewhat dampens the players will to continue. Net-code is also a bit creaky often resulting in players lagging terribly or getting lost entirely as connections drop. If it were not for these problems I would most certainly have given Tiny Brains a solid 7 out of 10 but for now I would suggest that this is definitely one worth picking up on a sale. Better yet pick up three other copies and gift to three friends because you are bound to get a good few laughs out of it in the process.

If you enjoyed reading this review please follow my curator group at:-
Curator Rater

reviewText:
Tiny Brains is an excellent co-op puzzle game that I think anyone can enjoy. It's not portal, but it's still an excellent game, what really makes this game shine is when you play it with a bunch of friends- and that's the point. If you're going to solo play this, I think your time is better spent, but as a co-op game its definitely a great experience to test friendships working out puzzles, since each person is handed a single tool in your toolkit.

My only complaint about the game is that I wish there were more puzzles, DLC is likely in the future, but even so when my friends and I did our first playthrough it only took us 90 minutes- there are some challenge modes, which are definitely great to extend it's lifetime, as let me tell you, working together with 3 other people to keep the ball on the endless rotating pillar is pretty exhillarting and full of suspense, and when you do fail you just try to do it better again.

Finally, I will say this, the game is available on the PS4, and if you have one I would reccomend you get this game for the PS4 instead. The game's strength is as a couch co-op/party game. Its easy to play, it's kid friendly (if you're wondering) and the single player mode just honestly doesn't bring the same entertainment playing it with friends is. As of this moment, I think this is the best party game to get for a PS4, definitely something to grab if you were looking for a reason to invite your buddies over to play your PS4 with you.

reviewText: This game is a blast to play, though it was a little glitchy/laggy at times. This was to be expected though, as my friends and I were playing co-op over not necessarily so good internet connections, but it didn't detract from the game very much. We were all extremely sad to realize that there was no way to do Tiny Soccer or Troll Mode via online connections, however, as we worked hard to get all 20 cheeses and had been so excited to get to play Troll Mode together and just be ridiculous derps. It would be amazing if online co-op for these modes could be enabled, as we all would probably play the game for many more hours as a result. Otherwise it was a great challenge, and we had a ton of fun shouting at each other over skype to do this or be this Tiny Brain. :)

reviewText: Tiny Brains is a small game that is best played with friends. reviewText: What an amazing breath of fresh air, this puzzle game is. Amongst all of the similar platformers and shooters and everything in between, this game somehow manages to bring back that hilarity that we so enjoyed on a snow day at a friend's house. It can be played alone, but the game really does shine when you are playing with others. If you can't do local or friends (which is preferred, you won't want to miss those moments), you can still play with others online, and it is simply a blast. The characters are lovable and zany, and the story completely out of left field, as to be expected from indie publishers. The game has a few kinks that need to be ironed out, and the story is quite short, but the challenges and extra modes don't get old when you play with friends - it's an overall very positive experience. 8/10\nP.S: Beat the Jules mode to get the best achievement to ever grace our mortal kind!

reviewText:
Overall, this is a fun little romp when you have 3 or 4 local couch co-op players available. In my opinion, there is some wasted potential here, but it works. Tiny Brains boils down to giving each player a very specific 'power' which they can then work as a group to solve puzzles. In general, the puzzles are trying to get out of a single room (move the 'key' to the slot kind of thing). The theme is science. It could be better executed, but because this is such a niche genre (4 player puzzle solving) it gets a pass. I hate saying that. In general I think it suffers from some blandness that often is associated with AAA titles. Although I have no idea what the budget was for this game - there were many people in the credits.

Try the demo - it is a decent length.

Pros:
+Science theme is cool enough
+Controls work fine
+Puzzles have a medium difficulty - could have been more difficult IMO, but it was fine

Cons:
-Some levels have fighting elements which I would rather do without - just stick to the puzzles
-Voice over is real meh
-Graphics are bland, needed someone to make stronger artistic decisions, IMO
-Better in short play sessions to keep it from feeling repetitive
-I know this sounds really silly and picky - but it bothered me when all the people in the credits had the Dr. title - I know its in the theme, but it just bothers me

Its a steal if you can get it on a sale. Try the demo - it speaks for itself.

reviewText:
Tiny Brains is an incredibly stupid co-operative game.  It tries to hit the same spark that Portal did all those years ago, but is held back with strange & sometimes buggy graphics and programming, not to mention finicky collision boxes and sub-par voice acting.

That being said, you should totally play it.

If only for a couple hours, playing it with friends is a hilarious experience.  Though the puzzles are clever at times, there is usually a way to cheese your way out of doing it the right way, and the different characters and abilites are fun to mess around with, and completing the game is satisfying.  It's a great way to kill time; even if you only play it once, that will be enough.

Not to mention one of the best ending songs I've heard in a game.

reviewText:
Tiny Brains wants to treat you like its minuscule rodent protagonists.

A coop focused puzzle game, you play as one of four furballs who through some bizarre experiment have been given superpowers and are now naturally stuck running through tests to deduce just how intelligent they've become. Where Spearhead takes this so far however is in seemingly forgetting to design its puzzles as anything requiring involved thought or clever utilization of its awkwardly implemented mechanics.

There's this feeling throughout playing Tiny Brains like you're running on a treadmill through the tutorial for all of its four very brief levels. It reuses the same puzzle types, repeats similar level designs, and never gets around to taking the training wheels off. You're a rat in a maze doing the same things again and again. And that's really boring.

More frustrating still is how poorly it makes use of its coop component. It's very clearly the way Tiny Brains was designed to play, but puzzles rarely requires the use of more than one or two different powers, essentially meaning if you're playing a full game of four you'll be trading off who gets to actually do anything instead of using your combined efforts to progress. It's at this point that you're probably asking why you wouldn't simply play solo, and the answer to that lies in the aggravating handful of levels that make playing solo immensely difficult or downright impossible. I'm fairly certain I cheated through several of the last levels as there didn't seem any way to possibly get through them without the help of more players, and at one point was attempting to use two controllers simultaneously to get past what was still a very rudimentary puzzle.

And then there are all the portions which don't center around puzzle solving at all, but instead rolling a giant ball through an obstacle course or protecting a little pink chick from a horde of rampaging chickens. These are without question the worst parts of an already miserable game, and besides being terribly boring are often obnoxiously difficult because of the poor controls and annoying cooldown timer. These portions probably take up about a third of the game, which is only an hour or two long to begin with. I'd take a moment here to write a bit more about how the before mention pink chick, ostensibly the sole female character in the game, is used solely as a victim and a villain and feels just a little sinister and problematic, but the dialogue is so cringe inducing and the narrative flimsy that there's hardly any point.

Everything just comes together like a giant mess of bad design, not helped by the abundant technical issues (as of this writing online coop is all but entirely broken, and even playing solo I experienced crashes after every chapter). I love what Tiny Brains was going for with a coop puzzle game with some unusual means with which to solve them, but it fumbles the whole way and never does anything with its concepts that it just wants to keep introducing over and over. Getting through Tiny Brains would have been a chore even had it worked as intended, but the sort of disrepair its in just makes it sad and embarrassing, and I feel a little bad for having made others play it with it.

reviewText:
A funny little game. Unfortunately it is way to short (only 3h playing with friends) and it has some minor bugs.

We encountered synch problems regarding the position of some players. Also some minor graphic bugs after reconnects due to connection loss ... weird screens, black screens and such things, all of them were resolved after restarting the game.

I would recommend playing this game with a controller ... mouse + keyboard are rather annoying ...

I can't say anything about solo play, as I think this game is not meant to be played like this and I have never done it.

A bit to expensive for it's shortness but fun ... maybe we will see some DLCs  in the future to lengthen the play time.

reviewText:
This game is awesome if you have 3 friends to play with. I definitely suggest it for those of you I know (especially you and those you know, Scooter).

It is sort of like Portal Multiplayer, but with 4 people. You go through wonderfully crafted levels and figure out puzzles by using all of your powers together to accomplish different goals. The campaign is a bit short (maybe 6-10 hours tops) but the challenge modes are addicting.

There are about 3 (if I remember correctly) endless mini-games, where you might need to work together to roll a ball as far as you can up a hill, or save a target from dying. It's really challenging and can get addicting as you try to get the top score (ahem, Blough).

reviewText:
First thing you'll learn is that the game has annoying unskippable cutscenes.

But as you most likely will be interested in Co-Op and Local Co-Op: they don't work.

Standard Xbox 360 controllers connected, work fine in all other games, this game will not see the second controller.

Also the game has been abandoned by the developers. No patches etc.

So in case you're in for the multiplayer: don't buy.

reviewText:
A brief but memorable experience. Tiny Brains is a commendable attempt at creating a unique co-operative multiplayer experience that can be enjoyed in a single play session. The controls and concepts are straight forward enough for less experienced players to succeed, while still presenting an entertaining challenge to gaming veterans. It's a great title to play with a few friends on Steam Big Picture for an enjoyable evening of collaborative physics-based puzzle solving.

Some areas of the game can be difficult to execute and may try your patience, but conquering these sections is bolstered by a wonderful feeling of group accomplishment.

Tiny Brains is easy to recommend to anyone looking for a fun and unique title to explore with family or a few friends. With any luck more developers will take chances on games like Tiny Brains.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Tiny Brains is a decent enough puzzle-platformer for two or more players. I can not imagine playing it alone, so make sure you have someone with you, as the game is not just for two players, it is pretty much only enjoyable this way.

Anyway, you control four mice that have unique powers(Push, Suck, Switch-positions, and Freezing) and all their powers combine to help you get through the increasingly harder levels. The game has a cute look and the puzzles are usually quite satisfying to solve.

However, the game does lean towards being very rage-inducing. Some of the puzzles involve keeping a little critter alive while it is being attacked by waves on enemies. It's not fun and can drive just about anyone made. Other puzzles involve pushing a ball through a complicated hole-filled maze. They are not fun, either.

The majority of the puzzles, though, are wonderful little rooms(think of Portal) that require solving something in order to open the exit. These are all great and a lot of fun to solve with a friend. If they make a sequel, they should focus on these kind of puzzles exclusively.

Room puzzles - 8/10

Non-room puzzles - 4/10

Overall, this game is worth 6/10 to me.

reviewText:
tiny brains is a puzzle game where you have to solve each puzzle to advance to the next stage with the help of *tiny brains*.
the game consist of four characters ,or tiny brains, to each their own ability and need in certain situations; as a single player you can switch between each one of them, however, one of the downsides is that as a single player you can only go so far without the help of others.
multiplayer is just the cherry on the cake; their will be times where you cry and others where you laugh.. so why not experience these emotions with friends?.
the game tends to get very glitchy at times regardless of your internet connection... which is a major downside for the game since accuracy and timing are very important to solve puzzles.
over all its worth the money 7/10

reviewText: If i had to describe this game in one word it would be amazing. This is an amazing puzzle game in which you can play 1-4 players each play as 1 of 4 different tiny lab rat like characters called the tiny brains there's Dax the super sonic bat that can push things away from him, Pad the quantum brain mouse that switches places with objects, Minsc the ice bear thing who creates an ice block, and Stew the super charged rabbit who pulls things towards him. The story is very short but there is a lot of extra content to keep you busy like jules mode where you have all the powers of the tiny brains but can't respawn, troll mode where you play as human versions of the characters but there is friendly fire, the ball chalenges they can be very difficult and fun, and soccer where you play in teams of two and you all have all the powers. I REALLY suggest that you guys get it, it's only $20 on steam and a lot of fun.

reviewText:
This is a weird game.  Let's get that out of the way first.  Tiny Brains is a fun little romp, created by indie startup Spearhead Games.  These guys made, easily, one of the funniest little bits of gaming I've ever seen in recent memory.  That being said, Tiny Brains does miscalculate at points and occasionally it feels like you already went through something.  Bear with me here.


First, let's talk gameplay.

You play as one of four superpowered rodents (Technically five, although I'm not divulging due to spoilers), which all have a unique, physics-bending, power.  One can pull stuff in, another can create a block of ice which can either act as a trampoline or wall, or can be affected by the other Brains' powers, another shoves stuff away, and another swaps places with some object, BUT cannot affect the Brains themselves.  The game is, put bluntly, a puzzler.  You need to combine and conquer with powers, using two, three, sometimes all four at once just to get past a puzzle.  It's a devious piece of work - At times I was forced to take a step back, re-analyze my strategy, and then adapt to whatever I was coming up on.

That's the good news of gameplay.  The bad news?

The Brains, for starters, move a tad bit too slow.  It's not a HUGE issue, but in some cases, it does glare right through, most notably in the challenge mode.  Also, unfortunatly for the poor install base (I think it's small), this game was MEANT to be a co-op game, and playing single-player can sometimes feel less like a game and more an exercise in how to non-standardize puzzles.  It's still OK, but friends = Good.

Now, for the graphics.  They're...Weird.  This game was meant to be a PS4 release title, but it got shoved back some.  The graphics themselves are cartoony fun, mixed with horrifically dark themes.  It makes for an oddball experience, oftentimes completely clashing with it's silly premise.

The game itself takes, at best, two and a half hours to complete, more if you want to see everything ever.  This game is good fun, but I'd get it on a sale - 20$ seems a little too much an asking price for a package this tiny (Heh).

Overall, I'd buy Tiny Brains.  And so should you.
voteText: No ratings yet

Some areas of the game can be difficult to execute and may try your patience, but conquering these sections is bolstered by a wonderful feeling of group accomplishment.

Tiny Brains is easy to recommend to anyone looking for a fun and unique title to explore with family or a few friends. With any luck more developers will take chances on games like Tiny Brains.

this game i will be comparing with portal because they both use physics based puzzles but tiny brains more or so focuses on more fast reflexes and sharp wits to find out the answer. single player is harder you have to switch between rodents and multiplayer you have to find a way to communicate.

Level 2 graphics
these graphics are not the best graphics but thats what it is its supposed to be funny with all the scientists refrences and just genuine good humor and it is definetly a colourfull game.

Verdict
This game is a indie game that deserves more love and is an intriging gameplay and extra modes and the best trophy/achivement (dont think its on xbox) the completionist a great youtuber that i watch daily at thatonevideogamer so watch his review and see if you want to pick it up i give this game a 8/10 amazinga

reviewText:
For ‚Ç¨2 in sale, this game is OK. But it's definitely not worth the regular price of ‚Ç¨10. It's really short, but a fun co-op challenge while it lasts. And with short, I don't mean a single evening, but with short I mean watching a movie would take longer...

The game had lots of repetitive content aswell (moving a ball through a gauntet, defending a single cube with health). On top of that the game was very laggy the closer we got to the end where more things were happening at once.

Would recommend it on sale, if you play it LAN / Local, but definitely not for regular price, and for online the performance is poor.

Online co-op doesn't work and devs abandoned game. Seems fun, but it's really a local co-op only game. Plus, it seems like you can really only get a few hours of play time out of this, based on reviews, so definitely not worth the 10 bucks.

reviewText: Tiny Brains is a lot of fun for people who have friends or siblings that can join in and make the fun happen in local co-op. I was able to play this with my two younger sisters, one being 6 and the other being 11 years of age, and we were able to finish the main story in 2 hours. It was frustrating at times (probably due to their ages), but it was a lot of fun and a great puzzle co-op game for all ages to enjoy. However, because there were three of us and this is a 4 player game, having to switch between characters was a bit tedious at times. But if you can get together 3 people it is a lot of fun! And for afterwards there's even a soccer mode and some variations to the main story that you can mess around in with your co-op partners. Although the price is a little steep for the short experience, so I'd recommend picking it up in a sale.\n\nEnjoy! :)

reviewText: Tiny brains is a geniusly well put together game where you can either collaberate with friends for hours on end or tease your own brain.\n\nIt's good to take a break from the occasional shoot em' up games that you see every day, something to work your brain while having some good laughs as well. If you let the appearance of it at first fool you, you should take another glance at it and when you find it on sale (not saying it's worth its original price) pick it up and try it out sometime :) i promise you will not be dissapointed.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
It's a nice puzzle co-op game. The problem is, the gameplay is a bit disjointed. Probably the best way to play it and get the most fun of it, is to play it full 4 player co-op. That way four different people will get four different characters with four different powers. Having 2 player co-op or 3 player co-op leaves somebody to switch characters with different powers on the go, which could be problematic and frustrating.

To the game's credit, it is possible to fully pass the game in 2 or 3 player co-op. But that leads to my other problem with the game - it's short. Really short.About 2,5 - 3 hours of gameplay.

The humor is fine and cheeky. But visualy the style is undefined and, personaly, hurts my eyes a bit.

After all of the above, I would only recommend this game if it's on sale AND you have 3 other friends that want to play a short, nice, little co-op puzzle game.

reviewText: Absolutely love this for local co-operative play, it is heaps of fun and has some great puzzles and mini games for replayability, great for kids. Only problem is the glitches, for example if someone leaves the game, its nearly impossible to kick them without disconnecting their controller and rebooting the game. Another is players respawning in places where it is impossible to complete the level without restarting. These can make Tiny Brains a really frustrating experience!

reviewText:
Picked up the game during a sale for 99ct and was worth every penny.
We had a blast playing this sort of puzzlegame with 4 four player over internet with steam friends.
In the forum some of the people seams not to be able to set up a coop game, but it seams those are eather wrong or for an older version. We had no issues.
The difficulty level goes up during the second chapter.
At a point on chaper 3 we had to give up where you apperently had to swich a char in a mid air jump, but maybe we are just not skilled enouth for that :-)

Game compairs to Portal2 and Trine. Its fun to play with friends. I would recomend to pick up a controler to play.
